documents.title: that 's everything we have time for
text: and with that , michael has to go and spread his very even-handed gospel elsewhere .
many thanks to him for all his thoughtful answers .
the next culture webchat is on monday , with candi staton the callout for questions will be launched later today .
jackarist asks : dear professor sandel , first and foremost , thank you for all the work you have done not only challenging market faith but also inspiring thousands to begin philosophical inquiry .
at the end of democracy 's discontent you say , since human beings are storytelling beings we are bound to rebel against the drift to storylessness .
could you expand on this and the shared narratives we all share .

thank you again , being a math/econ undergrad student with a passion for philosophy i am indebted to you for not falling into the trap of believing that markets are the panacea to every problem we have .
guardian contributor michaelsandel 24 october 2014 1:07pm shared narratives are what hold communities together .
the ability to tell stories is to see one 's life as part of a larger story .
and so the capacity for narrative is what situates us in the world .
by the drift to storylessness , i mean the tendency in modern life to think of ourselves without reference to larger frameworks of meaning and belonging .
one of the great moral and civic challenges of our time is to recover our capacity to tell compelling stories that relate our identities to shared communities of value and meaning .

stiglitzsandelplato asks : professor sandel , i am a long time admirer of your work , enjoying numerous documentaries by you , your harvard course , and particularly what money ca n't buy : the moral limits of markets .
you write a strong critique of the market society we live in , and thus of the overreach of markets .
you also consider a wide variety of social and moral issues in your book justice and the harvard course .
considering this background , why do you not consider a perfect outlet of your examples : the meat industry ?

factory farming is the perfect example of the overreach of markets , corrupting the goods , or animals , that are being bought and sold , and continued striving for efficiency leading to ever greater cruelty to the animals .

you provide reasoned critiques of the market , and even cruelty to animals in bearbaiting ( plus indirect mentions of factory farming in relation to the consensual cannibal ) in your books , so why is there no critique of factory farming in your books ?
many thanks , joshua parikh guardian contributor michaelsandel 24 october 2014 12:56pm you are right to suggest that factory farming raises serious ethical questions .
there 's the matter of cruelty of course , and also the moral problem of treating animals in a purely instrumental way .

i 've been helped in my thinking about factory farming by discussions with my son , who is a vegan ; although i am not myself a vegetarian i have to say that my son 's ethical arguments for veganism are not easy to dismiss .

documents.title: three favourite philosophers ? `` aristotle , kant and hegel ''
text: james hitchins asked : hi michael , i 've loved your radio 4 programs , and i 've read quite a lot of your work .
i 'd be interested to know who are your 3 favourite philosophers ?
thanks , james london .
guardian contributor michaelsandel 24 october 2014 12:48pm aristotle , kant , and hegel .

all three , though in very different ways , offer ways of thinking about politics and ethics that can help us question the familiar utilitarian , market-driven , assumptions that inform contemporary life .
johnmckeeesu asks : hi michael , a large part of the thesis of your book what money ca n't but : the moral limits of markets is that market norms ' crowd out other civic norms ' .

one example amongst many you use is that of the kinder garden where parents where paid to turn up on time to collect their children , but it seemed the financial incentive correlated with a decrease in parents their children on time .

some , such as the chicago economist john gist ( who is a recent co-author with the guy who ran that experiment , uri gneezy ) have suggested that we have no evidence that crowding out is what is occurring here , and suggests a different ( similarly non-verified hypothesis ) that in fact new information is being added - in this instance the information being being late to up my children is a cheap price ' .

this is distinct from crowding out since no pre-existing information is discarded or even prioritised , simply that more data available to the decision maker permits them to come to a different conclusion .
what would you response to this criticism be ?
thanks for your time !
guardian contributor michaelsandel 24 october 2014 12:44pm i do n't agree that this result can be explained without reference to changing norms .
for those unfamiliar with this example , the daycare centre was trying to deal with the problem of parents coming late to up their children .
they established a fine for late arrivals and paradoxically , late arrivals increased .
so how to explain this ?
my explanation was that parents treated the fine as if it were a fee and the ability to pay for a late arrival crowded out the sense of obligation to arrive on time .

before , parents who came late felt guilty , they were imposing on the teacher who had to look after their child waiting for them to arrive ; once they could pay for a late arrival the guilt disappeared .
it was as if they were simply hiring a babysitting service .

it may be the case that when the fine for late arrivals was established it provided parents new information , but the real question is what is the relevance of this information for the behaviour of the parents ?
one needs to explain why the `` information '' conveyed by the price for late arrivals led more parents to arrive late .
so the purely informational account begs the question : it 's true that if they raised the price high enough , say to a million dollars for a late arrival , no parent would arrive late .
the price effect at that level would work .
but the interesting point of this example is that the price effect sometimes competes with an independent effect to do with the crowding out of social norms .
zibibbo asks : you famously taught a highly acclaimed course on social justice for two decades at harvard to perhaps the most influential people on the planet .

indeed , such was the regard for these courses , that the bbc broadcast a number of them both on radio and tv which showcased your even-handed , reasonable , mild-mannered and impeccably argued approach to the subject .
and yet here we are in 2014 with no perceptible change in the paradigm of free market fundamentalism and ever growing social inequality that is so evident on both sides of the atlantic .
things actually seem to be getting worse .
do you sometimes think you should invoke a more polemical , urgent style of presentation to press home your important insights regarding fairness and social justice ?
is there a danger that your rhetoric is too anodyne to impress itself on the elite , ivy-league/oxbridge opinion formers and legislators of tomorrow ?
guardian contributor michaelsandel 24 october 2014 12:34pm this is an interesting challenge , thank you for raising it .
it 's fair enough to suggest that my approach is too gentle and reasoned , and insufficiently polemical .
but here 's why i teach and write the way i do .
my aim is to encourage , invite , and provoke students , viewers and readers to subject their moral and political views to critical examination .
my goal is to promote a more morally engaged public discourse than the kinds to which we 're accustomed .
the more combative , polemical style of presentation might make my views about justice and equality and markets more vivid .

but as my aim is to promote a more thoughtful , ethically engaged kind of public discourse , i would rather try to cultivate in students and viewers and readers , the capacity to listen attentively and to reason passionately but respectfully with one another .
you are right that we have a long way to go .

i could be wrong but i believe that encouraging the leaders of the future to be more reflective about themselves and their ethical views may be a more effective way of improving public discourse in the future .
rebeka vasrã©ti asks : dear professor sandel !
i would like to pose a very important question : if there is a right to political democracy , why this principle is n't applied also to economic democracy ?

to put it differently : if our right to participate in public decision making is widely accepted ( at least in western countries ) why do n't we have a right to participate in communal decision making at our workplace ?
and here i would like to emphasize that the workplace is the social sphere where we contribute to the common social wealth the most .
of course , this question implies a few others about self-management , communal autonomy etc .
many thanks , rebeka vasrã©ti guardian contributor michaelsandel 24 october 2014 12:26pm you ask a very good question about the relation between political democracy and economic democracy .
the underlying principle of democracy is that people should have a meaningful say in shaping the forces that govern their lives .
individually and collectively .
if this is the fundamental principle underlying democracy , then it can reasonably ask whether democracy should play a part in the workplace .
not only that , deliberating about decisions in the workplace can provide a kind of civic education that equips citizens to deliberate well in politics .
so there is a strong case for exploring ways of enabling participants in the workplace to contribute to decision-making .
not only as a way of protecting their own interests but also as a way of giving them a voice in promoting the common good that their company or workplace serves .

id0166222 asks : dear professor sandel , i would be very interested on your thoughts on the sale of eu citizenship ( a plan announced by malta last november , but recently curtailed ) , can this be seen as a communal good being commodified ?
if so , does unfair process and corruption always follow as expressed in what money ca n't buy ?
many thanks , sophie guardian contributor michaelsandel 24 october 2014 12:22pm yes , this is a very good example of the extension of market logic into every sphere of life .
a number of countries now are effectively selling citizenship .
malta as you mentioned is one example ; spain and portugal have so-called 'golden visa ' programs that essentially allow people to buy the right to reside in those countries .
and given the rules of the eu if one country sells citizenship or sells passports , those countries are turning eu citizenship into a commodity .
gary becker , a famous free market economist , has gone so far as to argue that countries should put citizenship up for sale .
a market solution to the immigration debate .
but this raises the question whether the meaning of citizenship is degraded and corrupted if turned into a commodity .
consider this extension of the market logic : should existing citizens of a country be able to put their own citizenship up for sale , and trade places with someone willing to pay them enough money ?
it could well be argued that the selling of citizenship is intrinsically corrupting .
the reason is that citizenship is a form of identity , a form of membership in a political community that carries rights and duties that money should not be able to buy .
bill mitchell asks : thanks for doing this discussion , prof. sandel .
as you look at the current media landscape , what strikes you as some of the more interesting ethical challenges for journalists these days ?

guardian contributor michaelsandel 24 october 2014 12:16pm the media today faces a serious financial crisis , and this has led to financial pressures that often distort news coverage and distract the media from issues that really matter .
too often media coverage is driven by scandal and sensationalism .
as a result , there are fewer and fewer places in the media for discussion and debate of the big questions that we should be debating in politics .

to enable at least some parts of the media to provide forums for a richer public discourse we may need to experiment with new financial models for the support of the media , including possibly not-for-profit structures .
the growing financial pressures these days make it very difficult for the media to play the role that it should play in promoting active and engaged democratic citizenship .

ben franta asks : climate change can be characterized by two features : the long investment horizon of mitigating emissions ( > 30 years ) and the global commons nature of climate change impacts , which are experienced disproportionately by the poor and vulnerable .
morality-based arguments for mitigating climate change in reaction to these features are beginning to arise in popular movements under the umbrella term of climate justice .
what is your perception of the climate justice movement ?
do you see connections with other justice movements ?
are there moral norms the climate justice movement will need to establish in order to be successful ?

guardian contributor michaelsandel 24 october 2014 12:12pm there are at least two reasons to care about climate change : one as you suggest can be characterised as `` climate justice '' , focusing on the disproportionate effects of climate change on the poor and the powerless .
a second reason is that we need to overcome the tendency to regard and treat nature in purely instrumental terms .
to deal with the challenge of climate change we need to cultivate an ethic of shared sacrifice , based on a respect for nature .
to do this we need to rein in the hubris that goes with thinking that we stand astride the natural world , and can exercise unlimited mastery over it .
cultivating an ethic of shared sacrifice and respect for nature may help us address both of these reasons to care about climate change .
birkos asks : dear dr sandell , i believe that everyone has a personal and civic duty to keep reasonably fit and i accept this is best achieved by education , persuasion and public discussion .
you have illustrated the problems of using financial incentives in diverse areas such as encouraging reading , organ donations etc .

however , in the case of severely overweight people , would you consider it ethical and effective to offer the obese financial incentives to shed weight and maintain weight loss over a period of time .
i understand this is a subtle form of coercion but surely it is the least worst option .
this could also apply to smoke and drug cessation programmes .
kind regards and thanks .
rhys guardian contributor michaelsandel 24 october 2014 12:08pm some people view cash incentives to lose weight or to quit smoking as `` health bribes '' .
this reflects the view that we should n't have to be paid to look after our own health , and possibly paying people to do what they ought to do without payment can erode personal responsibility .
in extreme cases , such as the ones you suggest , a bride might help .
but it is important to remember that a bride substitutes a lower motivation for the proper one .
the challenge is not to become dependent on the bribe , not to give up on the higher aim of educating people to care for their health for the right reasons .

documents.title: post your questions for michael sandel
text: in the age of ted , moocs and other zingy digital acronyms , a teacher who might previously have only been revered within the walls of their institution can break out , put on a hands-free microphone , and assume the mantle of a rock star .
michael sandel is one such figure .

his class entitled justice grew to become one of the most popular in harvard university , for its exploration of moral decision-making that linked aristotle and kant through to the problems of today it then earned a worldwide audience after it was made available for free online .
but everyday justice is just one of sandel 's many inquiries : he has explored the ethics of genetic engineering , and the moral quandaries created by a shift towards a global marketplace .

the popularity of his clearly reasoned , morally anchored arguments has led to hit books like what money ca n't buy : the moral limits of markets , as well as a bbc four serialisation of the justice lectures .
if you 've ever wanted to follow him up on one of his points , now is your chance he is joining us to answer your questions from 11.45am bst onwards , on friday 24 october .
post yours in the comments below , and he 'll endeavour to ask as many as he can .
